column2: You can assemble a party of four adventurers and send them on quests. Quests can challenge many different skills and attributes, not just combat skill, so make sure to create a party with a diverse skill-set.

You can send the adventuring party you have assembled on a quest. Your party will be faced with various challenges, and their lives will be at risk. If they succeed, they'll gain experience points, gold and artifacts, and they'll bring something valuable back for you. You'll have to pay them a fee, though.

You can send the adventuring party you have assembled against an host leader that is targeting you. If they succeed, they'll gain experience points, gold and artifacts, and the threat to your realm will be eliminated. You'll have to pay them a small fee, though.

column1: # Difficulty Selection Screen & Starting Adventure Tombola

column2: The adventurers you assembled are ready for some action! They have identified several locations within your lands that are overrun with dangerous creatures and apparently rich with ancient treasure. Will this expedition be remembered as a disaster, or as a great deed?

The realm is under attack by landless outlaws. Our adventurers are ready to deal with this threat: by removing our enemies' leader, their forces will disperse, sparing us the trouble of having to go to war.
We have rookies in need of experience, here.

This is a safer and extremely simplified adventure option for rookie adventurers. Only lower level characters will actually get experience points, and there will be no special events, or artifacts rewards.
Let's go for something simple, yet challenging.
A battle! Your party is being assaulted by a mob of monsters. A party member must take point and fight the enemy leader, while the rest fend off the minions. Who's going to?

All of a sudden, the weather goes from decent, to bad, to absolutely terrible. The party must find shelter as soon as possible, but who's the best person for this job? Martially inclined characters are going to be better at this, as are druids, barbarians and rangers.

The local populace isn't too happy with heavily armed strangers roaming their land as they please. If only your adventurers could befriend them, these peasants might offer them shelter, directions and supplies, instead of being an annoyance. Who's going to act as the party face? Diplomacy is key, paladins, bards and shadows are great at this.

While the party has a general idea on where their destination is located, they don't have exact coordinates. Hitting the books for a few days would help with that. Who's going to delve into dusty tomes and frayed parchments? Learned characters are going to be better at this, especially wizards, bards and warlocks.

The adventurers hear suspicious noises ahead: dangerous creatures lurking about, surely. By being stealthy, the party might be able to avoid this fight. Who's going to lead this stealth mission? Rogues, shadows and monks are the best at this, and being good at intrigue is also going to help.

The adventurers hear suspicious noises ahead: guards on patrol, surely. By being stealthy, the party might be able to avoid this fight. Who's going to lead this stealth mission? Rogues, shadows and monks are the best at this, and being good at intrigue is also going to help.

The party's supplies are running dangerously low, and the adventurers are nowhere near a place where they could buy some. They'll have to rely on foraging and hunting from this point on. Who's going to take care of this task? Martially inclined characters are going to be better at this, as are druids, barbarians and rangers.

After a long day of marching, the party realizes they have been walking in circles for a while, and they need to get their bearings right, fast. Who's going to act as party guide? Martially inclined characters are going to be better at this, as are druids and rangers.

The whole area is littered with old ruins, small and large. Finding the correct dungeon entrance by dumb luck would take a while...perhaps the party can pinpoint the correct location through clues, logic and educated guesses. Characters with high learning are going to be the best at this task.

Your party has reached the location of the dungeon they aim to explore and loot. Before delving in, they have the chance to rest a bit and mend some of the minor wounds they have sustained so far. Who's going to act as party medic? Learned characters are going to be better at this, and those capable of casting healing magic will be the best.

The signs are clear: broken skeletal remains, dried blood splatters, pressure plates...this place is full of traps. A party member will have to try disarming them, or at least locating them before somebody gets hurt. Who's going to handle this dangerous task? Rogues and shadows are the best at this, and being good at intrigue is also useful.

The party comes upon a strange room, where wild magical phenomena seem to happen at random: flying rocks, small fiery explosions, sudden whirlwinds, and more. Navigating this place safely won't be simple. Learned characters are going to be better at this, and arcane casters like sorcerers, wizards and warlocks are perfect for the job.

This is the final battle! The ruthless [final_boss.GetFirstName] stands before the party, accompanied by a host of minions. If your adventurers can take this fiend down, riches, loot and glory will be right ahead... who's going to engage [final_boss.GetFirstName] in personal combat?
The desperate battle rages on, and [final_boss.GetFirstName] is still standing. Who's going to trade blows with [final_boss.GetFirstName]?
Success! Your adventurers have returned home richer, better armed and more confident than ever. They even brought back a valuable gift for you! Some local clerics hurry to heal their wounds.

Failure! Your adventurer party have sustained casualties, and the survivors were forced to retreat. Even worse, the foul [final_boss.GetFirstName], angered by the attempt on [final_boss.GetHerHis] life, has assembled a large host and is going on a rampage as we speak! This in now a military matter.

Failure! Your adventurer party have sustained casualties, and the survivors were forced to retreat. You won't be able to assign them a quest for a while. Some local clerics have offered to heal their wounds.

This is the final battle! Your adventurers have cornered [final_boss.GetFirstName] and [final_boss.GetHerHis] most trusted lieutenants. If your adventurers can take this opponent down, the realm will be safe again... who's going to engage [final_boss.GetFirstName] in personal combat?
Success! Your adventurers have returned home heavy with spoils, and [final_boss.GetFirstName] is no more. A hero's welcome - and magical healing, courtesy of the local priesthood - awaits them.

Failure! Your adventurer party have sustained casualties, and the survivors were forced to retreat. Even worse, the foul [final_boss.GetFirstName] is unharmed, and well aware of your attempt to kill [final_boss.GetHerHim].

column1: # Healing Opportunity & War Camp Adventure Tombola

column2: Your party has reached the location of the main enemy camp. Before beginning their infiltration, they have a chance to rest a bit and mend some of the minor wounds they have sustained so far. Who's going to act as party medic? Learned characters are going to be better at this, and those capable of casting healing magic will be the best.

Your party encounters a band of unsavory mercenary types along the road, and they seem to be looking for trouble. Perhaps violence can be avoided. Who's going to act as the party face? Diplomacy is going to be key, and a fighter is more likely to command the respect of these thugs.

Exploration was going well, but suddenly the party reaches a dead end, as the passage they were traversing is blocked by fallen rocks. They'll now have to take the long way around, unless they can press through by brute force. Who's going to try? Strong warriors are the best at this, and being martially inclined is also going to help.

The adventurers were ready for battle, but they run across an unexpectedly calm group of monsters. These creatures seem content to live peacefully in this place, but the party must traverse their territory. Someone has to parlay, convincing them the team isn't here to fight. Diplomacy is key, paladins and bards are especially good at this.

The local taverns and gambling dens are full of seedy mercenary types. With the right approach, some of them could become excellent sources of information. Who's going to do the talking? Diplomacy is key, with bards being predictably good at persuasion. Fighters are also more likely to command the respect of these thugs.

Assaulting a military camp to take out the enemy leader is no small feat. Breaking in without a strategy, is basically suicide. Who's going to lead the planning effort? Martially inclined characters are going to be better at this, especially fighters, paladins and barbarians.

Infiltration was going smoothly, then suddenly, somebody yelled "Who goes there?", followed by the unmistakable sounds of steel being drawn. The party needs to end this confrontation quickly. Who's going to take point and fight the patrol leader, while the others take out the regular guards?

The adventurers located the camp's supply depot. If they could drug the supplies with sedatives, infiltration would become much easier. Who's going to stealthily drug the supplies? Shadows, rogues and monks are the best at this, and being good at intrigue is also going to help.

The enemy leader is too well guarded - what the party needs is an effective diversion, something that can lure enough soldiers away from their posts. Who's going to handle this? The flashy magic of wizards, sorcerers and warlocks would be perfect for this, and high learning can help.

Disguised as enemy guards, the party was making swift progress through the camp - then, a drunken group of soldiers decided to start a brawl. A manipulative person may be able to talk their way out of this one. Diplomacy is key, with bards, shadows and sorcerers being especially favored.

Disguised as enemy guards, the adventurers were managing to progress unnoticed - then, they caught the eye of a few warpriests, who started berating them for not respecting some important religious custom, or something. This could devolve into a brawl...unless a learned person, like a cleric, wizard or paladin, can defuse the situation.
You and your enemy square off against each other. There is no turning back from this confrontation: either you will win, or you will die.

column1: # Lose Adventurer trait, gain former adventurer

column2: It has been many years since you last went on an adventure. People still talk about your glorious exploits from time to time, but that's all in the past.
Your adventurers have returned home, after a few skirmishes in the wilds. Hopefully, this will be a useful learning experience for them.

column1: #Asks ruler if they want to adventure

column2: Adventuring is dangerous business, with a high chance of suffering death or a life-changing injury. It's also an activity that is considered beneath the standing of a powerful ruler. You could still engage in it, if you so wish.
Adventuring parties need to be small and nimble. If you want to join, one of your adventurers will need to stay home.
With superior combat prowess, you quickly dispatch some of the approaching enemies. The rest of the mob quickly flees before you.
Your opponent didn't stand a chance. You are victorious!
Didn't send adventurers questing in the last 3 years
Didn't send adventurers questing in the last year
this character will experience increasing fatigue.
this character will recover some stamina.
exact location of destination is discovered.
failing to disarm the trap. Every party member is blasted.
entire party hurt by harmful magic.
the mercenary leader starting a lethal duel.
failing to blend in. Every party member is involved in a brawl.
